metadata.title: Dysphagia  Myasthenia Gravis in Children
synonyms: swallowing disorder  myasthenia gravis in children
deglutition disorder: myasthenia gravis in children
oral dysphagia: myasthenia gravis in children
pharyngeal dysphagia: myasthenia gravis in children
esophageal dysphagia: myasthenia gravis in children
difficulty swallowing: myasthenia gravis in children
dysphagia, oral: myasthenia gravis in children
dysphagia, pharyngeal: myasthenia gravis in children
dysphagia, esophageal: myasthenia gravis in children
swallowing difficulty: myasthenia gravis in children
myasthenia gravis in children: swallowing disorder
myasthenia gravis in children: deglutition disorder
myasthenia gravis in children: oral dysphagia
myasthenia gravis in children: pharyngeal dysphagia
myasthenia gravis in children: esophageal dysphagia
myasthenia gravis in children: difficulty swallowing
myasthenia gravis in children: swallowing difficulty
anatomical location body part affected: Muscle weakness occurs commonly in the eyes, pharynx, and proximal limbs(2)
description: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disease and neuromuscular disorder characterized by painless, fluctuating weakness and rapid fatigue of voluntary muscles.(1) Symptoms include ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), diplopia (double vision), strabismus (eyes do not line up while focusing), neck and limb weakness, recurrent falls, dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia.(2,57) Up to 15% of children with MG present only with symptoms involving the extraocular muscles (ptosis, diplopia, and strabismus).(3) In children, there are three subtypes of MG:
Neonatal MG (NMG): a disease that is transferred from a mother with MG to the infant during pregnancy. This is not a permanent condition and usually lasts only a few weeks(3,4)
Congenital myasthenic syndrome: a rare, nonimmune form of myasthenia gravis that is inherited from both parents as an autosomal recessive disease. Symptoms are lifelong(3,4)
Juvenile MG (JMG): an autoimmune disorder with an onset similar to the adult form of the disease(3,4)
reimbursement: Reimbursement for procedure will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Dysphagia refers to difficulty swallowing due to an inability to move food efficiently during the oral, pharyngeal, or esophageal phases of swallowing.(5) The oral phase includes sucking, chewing, and moving the food or liquid into the throat while achieving adequate lip closure. The pharyngeal phase is the initiation of the swallowing reflex, when the food is squeezed down the throat and the airway is closed off to prevent aspiration (food or liquid entering the airway) or choking. In the esophageal phase, the openings at the top and bottom of the esophagus move  the food or liquid to the stomach by relaxing and tightening.(6) Dysphagia symptoms associated with MG include difficulty chewing, drooling, nasal regurgitation of fluids, coughing after swallowing, and choking on foods and secretions(1,3,7) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: During a swallowing evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain tolerance, fatigue, and level of frustration. The time of day and the number of previous evaluations can affect the patient’s alertness and performance

Due to the difference between adult and pediatric swallowing issues, it is important that an SLP have competencies in dysphagia management for the particular population that they are evaluating and treating(11)

A team approach is often used for the evaluation of swallowing disorders due to the heterogeneity of diagnoses and the complexity of treatment. A team includes a representative from various disciplines, including an SLP, a pediatrician, a nutritionist/dietician, a nurse, an occupational therapist (OT), a psychologist, a social worker, and a physical therapist (PT)(11)

risk factors: NMG: pregnant mother has MG(3)–NMG occurs in 10–20%  of infants who are born to mothers with MG(52,54)
JMG: more common in females than males in cases that occur after puberty(4,10)

In a study in Taiwan, researchers collected data on children with MG from 1998 to 2011 and found that a preexistingallergic disease, specifically allergic conjunctivitis or atopic dermatitis, was associated with increased risk of developingMG. Risk was also increased for children with two or more concurrent allergic diseases(58)

overall contraindications precautions: Speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) are required to have graduate, postgraduate, or continuing education training specifically in dysphagia assessment and treatment(11)
To perform a videofluoroscopic swallowing study (VFSS), an SLP must have established competencies in the use and storage of barium used in VFSSs(12)

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and/or penetration of oral intake. Ensure that the patient and patient’s family are aware of potential aspiration risks and educated about strategies when appropriate
It is important to consider eating habits, food preferences, and cultural influences on eating during assessment and treatment

A myasthenic crisis might occur if the patient experiences a sudden paralysis or extreme weakness of respiratory muscles.(9) Symptoms include excessive fatigue, shortness of breath, and fast, shallow breathing. The patient requires immediate assisted ventilation in the event of a myasthenic crisis. In JMG, plasmapheresis (a procedure similar to dialysis that removes the plasma portion of the blood where the antibodies are located) is often used in the event of a myasthenic crisis(10)

Patients with MG present with fatigue. The SLP should schedule the evaluation during times when the patient is less likely to be fatigued. The swallowing evaluation might require multiple sessions to complete

contraindications precautions to examina: During a swallowing evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain tolerance, fatigue, and level of frustration. The time of day and the number of previous evaluations can affect the patient’s alertness and performance

Due to the difference between adult and pediatric swallowing issues, it is important that an SLP have competencies in dysphagia management for the particular population that they are evaluating and treating(11)

A team approach is often used for the evaluation of swallowing disorders due to the heterogeneity of diagnoses and the complexity of treatment. A team includes a representative from various disciplines, including an SLP, a pediatrician, a nutritionist/dietician, a nurse, an occupational therapist (OT), a psychologist, a social worker, and a physical therapist (PT)(11)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Note when MG was diagnosed; document the type of MG (i.e., NMG, JMG, congenital myasthenic syndrome)

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical management of MG. Typical medical management for MG includes Anticholinesterase medications (e.g., pyridostigmine, neostigmine)(8,10) Steroids(8,10) (steroids are used with caution for children because of side effects that include growth stunting, weight gain, mood alteration, hyperglycemia, hypertension, and susceptibility to infection) Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange)(8,10) Removal of the thymus gland (thymectomy). Thymectomy is usually considered only in cases of generalized JMG(2,10,13) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg)(8,10) According to the evidence-based  guidelines from the American Academy of Neurology, IVIg is probably effective in treating patients with MG and should be considered as part of the medical treatment for patients with MG(55) Cytotoxic drugs(10) Supportive respiratory therapy during a myasthenic crisis(10)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Ask a pharmacist or physician about the side effects of these medications. Pyridostigmine, an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor, is commonly used to treat MG and has the side effect of increasing salivary secretions(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Tests to diagnose MG include the following:

Edrophonium test (the Tensilon test): An injection of edrophonium might result in a temporary reduction of symptoms, indicating the presence of MG. Edrophonium serves to block an enzyme that breaks down acetylcholine.(3) Swallowing or speech evaluations can be performed before and after administration of Tensilon(14)
Usual tests for dysphagia might include the following:
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational, physical, or speech therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: The following can exacerbate the symptoms of MG increase of steroids, anemia, and some antibiotics.(16) Epilepsy has been associated with MG in children.(17) Does the patient have a history of pneumonia or respiratory infections? Does the patient indicate any lack of awareness or interest in food? Does the patient show any signs of dehydration or malnutrition (e.g., weakness, malaise, constipation)?(18) Does -With certain textures of foods or liquids?  -In different environments? -As meals progress? Patients with MG typically fatigue as the meal progresses and dysphagia worsens(2) -During certain times of day? Patients with MG often experience increased muscle fatigue and muscle weakness at the end of the day(15) -If fatigued? -With environmental distractions? -After taking certain medications?
history of present illness.body chart: Review the patient’s chart and weight history and note any significant changes in weight. Review medical chart for other evidence of malnutrition, such as poor wound healing or increased incidence of ulcers
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Symptoms of dysphagia associated with MG include -Oropharyngeal weakness(7) -Facial weakness and difficulty chewing(7,57) -Difficulty with jaw closure(15) -Inability or difficulty clearing oral secretions(13) -Absent gag reflex(13) -Coughing after swallowing(7) -Nasal regurgitation(1) -Esophageal dysphagia caused by cricopharyngeal spasm(19) -Chest congestion as a sign of aspiration(13)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. Other symptoms associated with MG include ptosis, diplopia, expressionless facial appearance, dysarthria, nasal vocal quality, and limb weakness(15)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document the respiratory status of the patient, including vital capacity, and include use of supplemental oxygen or mechanical ventilator. Respiratory failure can occur in patients with MG if the diaphragm and intercostals muscles are affected.(19)Myasthenic crisis refers to a paralysis or extreme weakness of respiratory muscles, requiring assisted ventilation(9)Document how the patient is coping with his or her illness. Are there behavioral symptoms indicative of psychosocial disturbance? Document how the child’s caregivers are coping. Refer to mental health professional as indicatedInquire about any hearing loss, chronic ear infections,and use of hearing aids or cochlear implants Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document any previous swallowing difficulties, respiratory difficulties, communication difficulties, motor disorders, or cognitive deficits
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Refer to medical charts and ask the patient or patient’s family about other problems, including depression, hearing loss, vision problems, heart problems, communication difficulties, and memory loss
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient or caregivers about other symptoms the patient is experiencing (e.g., excessive throat clearing, coughing while eating)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Things to consider include receive intervention services? If so, are they home, school, hospital, or clinic based? Does the patient attend school? Where does the patient eat? What types/textures of food? What is the patient’s eating schedule?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document if the patient uses any adaptive equipment to communicate (e.g., pen/paper, communication board). Does the patient self-feed?  Is the patient limited to eating only certain textures of food?
social and occupational history.living environment: Document with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, siblings)

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting):
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient use any adaptive devices for mobility, communication, or eating (e.g., adaptive spoons, cups)?Examine ergonomics and body mechanics related to self-feeding.  Patients with myasthenia gravis often have weak neck flexor and extensor muscles that lead to a drooping head posture(15)Examine motor function as it relates to self-feeding.  Refer to OT or PT for assessment. For detailed information regarding physical and occupational therapy for generalized muscle weakness andT708853Examine the range, rate, coordination, and symmetry of movement of the lips, facial musculature, tongue, pharynx, and larynx. An oral exam also allows for observation of the patient’s ability to follow instructions and attention span.(21) For patients with MG, oral mechanism weakness will come on gradually over the course of the evaluation as the patient continues to talk and/or use these muscles. Patients with MG sometimes exhibit “jaw claudication” (pain in the jaw resulting in increased difficulty chewing over time), as well as an intact ability to open the jaw (for talking or chewing), but impaired jaw closure(56)
observation inspection palpation includi: Assessment scales/checklists: There are several clinical assessment scales and checklists to evaluate infants and children; however, no universally accepted feeding assessment tool exists. Scales, surveys, and checklists are commonly used in the clinical examination but often do not include normative data, standardization, validation, or guidelines for interpretation. SLP knowledge of normal oral motor development and feeding function are essential when evaluating infants and children(24) -Clinical Feeding Evaluation of Infants (CFEI) scale: Evaluation of an infant’s ability to suck on a bottle and/or breast. Includes assessment of child’s feeding history, oral motor skills, oral tactile responses, suck-swallow-breath coordination, general motor control, and general physical state during feeding and swallowing(25) -Neonatal Oral Motor Assessment Scale (NOMAS): Evaluation of sucking in infants (up to 3 months of age). Aspects of sucking behavior are classified as normal, disorganized, or dysfunctional(26) -Pre-speech  Assessment Scale: Rating scale that examines swallowing and voice in children up to 2 years of age. Ratings include duration of the meal, amount of intake, food consistencies, positioning, sucking from a nipple, sipping from a cup, and coordination of suck-swallow-breath(27) -Oral-Motor/Feeding  Rating Scale: Lip, cheek, tongue, and jaw movements are rated during a typical meal. This scale can be used with children from 1 year of age through adulthood(28) -The Multidisciplinary Feeding Profile: A statistically based protocol for patients who are dependent feeders. Scaled ratings are made for posture, tone, reflexes, general motor control, orofacial structures, orofacial sensory input, orofacial motor control, ventilation, and functional feeding assessment(29) -Assessment Scale of Oral Functions in Feeding: Ratings of lip, jaw, and tongue movement during ingestion of liquids and solid foods. Assessment of sipping from a cup, coughing, gagging, and hypersensitivity associated with feeding and  swallowing. A checklist allows for indication of abnormal oral structures, oral reflexes, positioning, diet, utensils, and feeding(30) -Preschool Motor Speech Evaluation: Assessment of oral motor, oral sensory, and oral motor speech abilities in children aged 18 months to 5 years(31) -Dysphagia Disorder Survey (DDS): Standardized screening survey that can be used with children from 2 years of age through adulthood. Assesses body mass index, restrictions in food textures and viscosity, dependence in feeding, and need for special utensils or positioning. Provides information on the severity of the swallowing disorder and can be used as an outcome measure(32) -In a study conducted in the United States, researchers examined results from the DDS taken from a total of 654 individuals from two residential facilities to assess psychometric properties of the assessment. Individuals included in the study ranged from 2 to over 61 years of age. Researchers concluded that the DDS was factorially stable across the two samples of patients and demonstrated substantial internal consistency reliability. The DDS is a reliable and valid test for dysphagia and related feeding disorders in individuals aged 2+ years(60) -Nutrition and Swallowing Checklist: A tool developed to screen for nutrition and swallowing problems in persons with intellectual disabilities. The checklist format allows for caregiver involvement in identifying risks and managing swallowing difficulties(33) -Dysphagia Outcome and Severity Scale: A tool to assist the clinician in describing the level of severity (seven levels) of the dysphagia and in making recommendations for nutrition, diet, and independence(33)

VFSS/modified barium swallow study (MBSS)/videofluoroscopic examination (VFE): A VFSS is performed when the dysphagia team has concerns about the pharyngeal phase of swallowing and the complete swallowing sequence. A VFSS is completed in collaboration with a physician (radiologist or physiatrist).(11) Most clinical practices follow the protocol originally described by Logemann, and adaptations of this protocol for infants and children are described in Arvedson and Lefton-Greif.(34,35) The assessment must be age-appropriate  with regard to positioning, presentation, and viscosity of material.(1) The patient eats and drinks a variety of developmentally appropriate liquids and solids mixed with barium while images are recorded with videofluorography. All patients should be examined in the lateral and frontal positions to obtain information on movements of the swallow and symmetry of bolus flow and pharyngeal wall contraction. The SLP examines for the presence of aspiration and the effectiveness of presenting different food consistencies or of modifying posture.(11) In contrast to the CSE, the VFSS provides critical information on the pharyngeal phase of the swallow.(21) Given the unnatural surroundings, swallowing function observed during a VFSS is not necessarily identical to that used at mealtimes.(36) Other variables which can influence swallowing function include anxiety, fatigue, and medications.(37) Due to the harmful effects of ionizing radiation on children, a repeat VFSS should only be considered when there are specific questions that require answers from a repeat study; a VFSS should not be used frequently to monitor changes in swallowing.(38) During the VFSS, the following physiologic components might be observed:(37) -Lip closure (ability to contain a liquid bolus) -Lingual elevation (the back of the tongue is slightly elevated) -Tongue-to-palatal  seal -Bolus preparation/mastication -Bolus transport/movement of the tongue (movement of the bolus to the back of the oral cavity) -Initiation of the pharyngeal swallow (swallow should be initiated when the bolus reaches the region of the posterior oral cavity) -Soft palate elevation and retraction -Laryngeal elevation -Anterior hyoid excursion -Laryngeal closure -Pharyngeal contraction -Pharyngoesophageal segment opening -Tongue base retraction -Epiglottic inversion -Esophageal clearance -For detailed information on a VFSS for the pediatric population, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: Modified Barium Swallow (Pediatrics) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709077

Endoscopic assessment of swallowing function/fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES): FEES is performed to evaluate the anatomy and physiology of the pharynx and the larynx, pharyngeal swallow function, and the patient’s ability to manage secretions and swallow foods and liquids.(11) In addition, it can be used to explore a variety of diagnostic interventions, such as varying bolus consistency, varying posture, or making use of visual feedback for reinforcement.(39) After the insertion of the endoscope, the patient can engage in normal feeding behavior during the evaluation. Food must be light in color to enhance visibility (e.g., milk, pudding, yogurt, bread). FEES is preferred over VFSS when patients have safety issues related to radiation exposure or when they need retesting. Due to the invasive nature of the procedure, it might be difficult to obtain accurate representation of a normal swallow in young children.(24) The American Speech-Language-Hearing  Association has published several online documents relevant to the technical aspects of FEES and the qualifications required to perform FEES(40) -For detailed information on assessment of swallowing by FEES, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: Fiberoptic Endoscopic Evaluation of Swallowing (FEES) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709038

Ultrasonography: Infant sucking and oral transit times can be examined by ultrasonography, an instrumental procedure involving transducers that use high-frequency  sound waves to create images. In infants and children, the transducer is placed under the chin as they swallow liquid or food. The ultrasonographic scanner can display images of the nipple, tongue surface, hard and soft palates, and hyoid during infant feeding(11)

Pulse oximetry: Oximetry is used to evaluate hemoglobin oxygen saturation levels before and after feeding. Most infants have an oxygen saturation level of at least 95%. Low saturation levels (below 90%) indicate some degree of hypoxia(41)

Cervical auscultation: Cervical auscultation involves the use of a stethoscope on the lateral side of the thyroid cartilage to listen to sounds associated with breathing and swallowing patterns. Limitations of cervical auscultation include a lack of normative data and clear guidelines for interpretation of the procedure. In addition, many movements associated with swallowing are silent(24) -For detailed information on assessment of swallowing with cervical auscultation for the pediatric population, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: Cervical Auscultation (Pediatrics) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709101

Electromyography: This assessment of the myoelectric activity of muscles is sometimes used with adults but is not indicated for routine evaluation of swallowing in infants and children(24) -For detailed information on assessment of swallowing by electromyography, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: Electromyography ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709041

Esophagram: An esophagram differs from an esophageal screening performed in a VFSS in that it incorporates large bolus swallows of liquids with varying densities. The patient is usually examined swallowing during side lying or erect positions. The esophagram can be used to evaluate peristalsis, gastroesophageal reflux, and transit time if esophageal dysphagia is suspected(42,43)

Manometric studies of the pharynx and UES:(44) Esophageal manometry is a test that evaluates motor function of the UES, esophageal body and lower esophageal sphincter (LES) when there is suspected difficulties with motility or peristalsis. A catheter is placed through the nose into the stomach by a trained technician and pressure changes are recorded as the patient swallows(44) -For detailed information on assessment of swallowing by manometry, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: Manometry ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709040
relevant tests and measures.posture: Note any posture abnormalities that might interfere with swallowing (e.g., head tilt, unilateral weakness). Fatigue can affect posture in children with MG. For infants and children with dysphagia, it is important to consider which body position is optimal for swallow function, including positioning of trunk, limbs, shoulder, and head support.(61) Additionally, positioning interventions might involve specialized seating equipment; discuss appropriate options for specialized seating with the child’s occupational therapist or PT(61)Document if the patient is able to eat independently
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Vision and hearing screening should be performed to determine any barriers to communication and ability to follow treatment protocol
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: It is important to screen receptive language before a swallow evaluation to determine the patient’s ability to follow directions. If other communication difficulties are noted, evaluate as necessary. Patients with MG can have dysarthria due to fatigue of oral musculature.(20) A hoarse, breathy voice can result from myasthenic weakness of the laryngeal muscles.(15) For detailed information on the treatment of speech impairment inSpeech Therapy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Dysphagia treatment should be appropriate for the cognitive level of the patient. Children might be better candidates for dietary and environmental modifications than for techniques that require the application of certain strategies (e.g., head tilt). Epilepsy has been associated with JMG; refer to psychological reports as necessary(10,17)
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: The purpose of a swallow examination is to determine if the patient has dysphagia, to determine which function is disordered, and to establish any compensatory strategies (change in swallowing manner or food consistency) that would be safe and beneficial to the patient.(11)Consensus-based  templates for documentation of pediatric clinical feeding/swallowing assessments and VFSSs are available on the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association’s (ASHA’s) website(62)A CSE is usually the first part of a comprehensive swallowing examination or used as an initial screening to determine the need for further evaluation.(11) Historically, the lack of a gag reflex function was used as a measure of dysphagia, but this has been demonstrated as unreliable as the sole indicator of swallowing function.(11) The featuresa wet voice, weak voluntary cough, cough on swallowing, and delayed or prolonged swallow.(22) However, CSEs are poor at detecting silent aspiration (aspiration of food or liquid into the lungs without overt signs) and in determining the physiologic reason for a cough or a voice quality change. Due to its limitations, a CSE should be used as a complement to other instrumental measures, rather than in  isolation. If oral intake is considered relatively safe, the patient might be observed swallowing different consistencies of food during the CSE.(21) Cervical auscultation (the use of a stethoscope to assess swallow sounds and airway sounds) can be used during CSE at the discretion of the evaluating SLP.(21,23) Adapt the CSE to the developmental and cognitive level -A comprehensive case history and review of medical records(11) -Family interview -Assessment of oral structures and motor function. Note the appearance of the oral mucosa (e.g., any inflammation or infection that might affect the oral stage of swallowing) and any pooling of saliva in the oral cavity. An inability to swallow might cause the saliva to pool in the mouth. If applicable, evaluate dentition in terms of the number and appearance of teeth, level of oral hygiene, and general dental care.(11) Examine the facial, labial, and lingual ROM, speed, and strength. Examine velar elevation -Assessment of speech and vocal quality(11) -Assessment of feeding during a regular meal (when possible) to observe the patient’s skills in coordinating of respiration and swallowing in a natural environment.(11) Assess patient’s ability to achieve labial seal and contain bolus. Examine retrieval of different food consistencies from a spoon, cup, and straw -Assessment of the pharyngeal phase by using palpation. To assess tongue-based  function, hyoid motion, and laryngeal motion during a swallow, place one finger under the patient’s chin at the base of the tongue, the next finger on the hyoid bone, the next finger above the larynx, and the next finger below the larynx. Once your fingers are in place, instruct the patient to swallow -Observation of the effects of alterations in posture or other compensatory techniques to improve swallow(11) -Evaluation of the patient’s ability to comprehend instructions and use compensatory strategies, if developmentally appropriate -Evaluation of the patient’s salivary function by visual inspection of the oral mucosa, medication review, and medical history review. Symptoms of dry mouth include mouth pain, dry tongue, bleeding gums, cracked corners of the mouth, and overall dryness (nose, eyes, skin) -In children with a known diagnosis of MG and subjective complaints of swallowing dysfunction, a direct referral for an instrumental examination of swallowing (without having a CSE first) might be appropriate in order to quickly diagnose and manage pharyngeal dysphagia(59) -For detailed information on the in-depth  swallow evaluation of the pediatric population, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia

other: Patients with MG might be at risk for falls due to limb weakness; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and penetration of oral intake. Ensure that the patient and family/ caregivers are aware of the potential for aspiration and are educated about prevention strategies when appropriate
It is important to consider eating habits, food preferences, and cultural influences on eating to maximize nutritional intake

Patients with MG have exertion-dependent  symptoms that might cause them to feel uncomfortable and anxious. The anxiety might in turn lead to restlessness and contraction of muscles, creating increased weakness and decrease of function

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Dysphagia diagnosis and management is based upon the results of a comprehensive assessment that is performed by an SLP in collaboration with a transdisciplinary team that might include a pediatrician, a dietitian, an OT, a PT, a respiratory therapist, an otolaryngologist, a radiologist, a social worker, a gastroenterologist, and a neurologist. Each discipline might provide specific input and expertise on the patient’s swallowing problems and the treatment plan. The primary concern is to maintain and maximize the patient’s health status.(11) After the evaluation, a decision must be made about the patient’s ability to ingest food and water orally based upon the nature of the disorder and the patient’s ability to make adjustments(45)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The physician should rule out other causes of dysphagia that might also show similar symptoms (e.g., muscle weakness), such as stroke, TBI, malignancy, infections, inflammatory conditions, botulism, Guillain-Barré  syndrome, Moebius syndrome, muscular dystrophy, or heavy metal poisoning(13,57)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to an OT, PT, nutritionist, respiratory therapist, social worker, neurologist, otolaryngologist, radiologist, oral hygienist, or gastroenterologist as necessary. Refer patient and/or caregivers to a psychologist or counselor if signs of depression are present
treatment summary: Diet modification:  Changing the food and/or liquid consistency of a patient’s diet might assist in improving the safety and efficiency of the swallow, as well as reduce fatigue associated with eating. For example, if a patient reports fatigue while chewing, the diet can be changed to mechanical soft texture.(46) Foods that are chewy, spicy, crumbly, sticky, or include mixed textures (cereal and milk) should be avoided.(47) If the patient reports aspiration of liquids or difficulty containing the liquid in the oral cavity, the clinician might investigate the used of thickened liquids; however, it cannot be assumed that all patients benefit from thickened liquids.(48) Clinicians should rule out all other reasons for malnutrition (e.g., socioeconomic status) and explore all possible intervention options before recommending thickened liquids or altered diets. The clinician should also ensure (by observing modifications during VFSS), rather than assume, that aspiration is not occurring with thickened liquids –The United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) cautions consumers against using commercial gum-based thickeners (e.g., SimplyThick) for infants from birth to 1 year of age, especially when the products are used to thicken breast milk, as they are associated with a risk of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC)(63) –For detailed information on diet modification for dysphagia, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy –Compensatory ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T903567

Postural therapy:  Several postures have been examined to assist in changing the direction of the flow of foods and liquids for patients with dysphagia, including the chin tuck, head back, head rotation, and head tilt(48) –For detailed information on postural changes for dysphagia, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy –Compensatory , referenced above

Sensory stimuli:  Changing the taste, volume, temperature, or carbonation of food or liquid has been used as a way to heighten sensation and assist with delayed oral onset and/or delayed pharyngeal swallow.(11,46) More research is needed to validate these techniques to determine their effects on a variety of different types of patients(48) –For detailed information on changes to sensory aspects of the bolus for dysphagia treatment, see Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy –Compensatory , referenced above

Adaptive equipment:  Adaptive spoons, cups, and straws might be used to assist patients with the oral stage of the swallow. For example, if the patient has difficulty achieving a labial seal and cannot drink from a straw, a nonspill cup with a large handle might be useful as a facilitative aid. If anterior leakage continues, spoons can be used to place the liquid more posterior in the mouth(46)

Enteral feeding:  If the patient is unable to maintain an adequate level of safety by means of oral feeding, the feeding team might recommend enteral feeding (e.g., nasogastric tube, gastronomy tube). Counseling and education of the patient and caregivers should be provided by the SLP or feeding team.(11) Children who are fed enterally might have difficulty transitioning to oral feeding due to oral hypersensitivity and oral defensiveness(11)

For detailed information on treatment for dysphagia in childhood, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia in Childhood ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708938 . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Symptoms of dysphagia Improve patient and family knowledge about dysphagiaPatient and family

improved swallow function reduced aspira: Presence of aspiration (measured by presence of fevers, x-rays)(46)

Due to the harmful effects of ionizing radiation on children, a repeat VFSS should only be considered when there arespecific questions that require answers from a repeat study; a VFSS should not be used frequently to monitor changes inswallowing(38)
improved nutrition and hydration: Measures of liquid intake and skin turgor (refers to the skin elasticity; poor skin turgor is a sign of dehydration)(46)

maintenance or prevention: The SLP is responsible for educating the family and patient care staff about the needs of the patient regarding swallow safety
Patient and caregiver education about dysphagia, including the importance of nutrition and hydration, should be initiated if the patient is having swallowing difficulties
The therapist and evaluating team should educate the patient about stress reduction and energy-conservation  strategies to minimize the symptoms of MG
patient education: See Patient Information Series from the Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of America, Inc., at https://myasthenia.org/

See “Myasthenia Gravis Fact Sheet” at the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke website at https://www.ninds.nih.gov/Disorders/Patient-Caregiver-Education/Fact-Sheets/Myasthenia-Gravis-Fact-Sheet Note

Recent review of the literature has found no updated research evidence on this topic since previous publication on December 22, 2017 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
